instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / 20V 400ma / No Post
threads.message:
Hi,

This machine stopped working suddenly.
Like a wrote in the title, the amperage goes to 650mA and after a few seconds drops to 400mA.  CPU and SSD warm a little, but nothing special. 
Apparently, sound alike the Logic Board is going to boot normally. But there's no image on display; no image on external display; no backlight on display neither keyboard and no green light on "caps lock". Only trackpad clicking.
 
I already checked on microscope for corrosion signs, and there's no liquid damage. There's no sign of previous intervention on Logic Board or damage in any components.  

Checked all voltages of page 69 (Power Aliases), and all voltages are present. The only voltages that caught my attention were the <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G_PH1</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G_PH2</SIGNAL>. Both goes up to 0.9V, but if i'm right on a normal boot the voltage should drop to 0.6V, wright?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / 20V 400ma / No Post
threads.message:
Do you get CPU core voltage (L7210)?
Check it after 10-15 seconds.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / 20V 400ma / No Post
Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / 20V 400ma / No Post
threads.message:
Not good, CPU core shpuld drop (as above mentioned), when board really boots.
Test the board alone on the desk; only charger connected.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high?
You can try known good BIOS.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / 20V 400ma / No Post
threads.message:
Yes, i'm working on the desk only with the board and power supply.

I forgot to mention, that i already tried a known good bios file and IC.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V stable

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / 20V 400ma / No Post
threads.message:
Heat CPU with quality flux.
There may be accumulated crap underneath.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / 20V 400ma / No Post
threads.message: Any tips of how much heat and how much time?

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / 20V 400ma / No Post
threads.message:
You don't need to melt the balls; just burn eventually crap.
180-200 degreees C, for 15-20s should be good enough.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A / 20V 400ma / No Post
threads.message:
Already tried it, but still with the same behavior.

I'm not gona loose more time with this board.

Thanks 2informaticos!
